--- title: "Regression and Statistical Inference" --- ::: {.cell hash='03_regression_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-1_c846f3ceda458061b4d2723c915d616d'} ```{.r .cell-code} #1 data <- readRDS("C:/Users/Anjali/Downloads/Causal_Data_Science_Data (1)/Causal_Data_Science_Data/car_prices.rds") # Assuming your data is stored in a variable named 'data' data_dimensions <- dim(data) # Printing the number of rows and columns print(paste("Number of rows:", data_dimensions[1])) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> [1] "Number of rows: 181" ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} print(paste("Number of columns:", data_dimensions[2])) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> [1] "Number of columns: 22" ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell hash='03_regression_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_c2fb915e6a5e56525dc509748efc9dc1'} ```{.r .cell-code} #2 # ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> #> Call: #> lm(formula = price ~ enginetype + cylindernumber + enginesize + #> stroke + peakrpm, data = data) #> #> Residuals: #> Min 1Q Median 3Q Max Assuming 'enginetype' is a categorical variable str(data$enginetype) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> chr [1:181] "dohc" "dohc" "ohcv" "ohc" "ohc" "ohc" "ohc" "ohc" "ohc" "ohc" ... ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Unique values it can take on unique_values <- unique(data$enginetype) print(unique_values) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> [1] "dohc" "ohcv" "ohc" "l" "ohcf" "dohcv" ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell hash='03_regression_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-5_0a9405abf746712e834c0bd5bdcc901c'} ```{.r .cell-code} #4.2 & 4.3 # Fit a linear regression model with 'enginetype' as the only predictor model_enginetype <- lm(price ~ enginetype, data =data) summary(model_enginetype) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> #> Call: #> lm(formula = price ~ enginetype, data = data) #> #> Residuals: #> Min 1Q Median 3Q Max #> -11599 -4237 -2171 1872 30223 #> #> Coefficients: #> Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) #> (Intercept) 18116 2031 8.919 6.15e-16 *** #> enginetypedohcv 13284 7324 1.814 0.07142 . #> enginetypel -4324 3346 -1.292 0.19802 #> enginetypeohc -7025 2121 -3.312 0.00112 ** #> enginetypeohcf -4378 2725 -1.606 0.10999 #> enginetypeohcv 6982 2817 2.479 0.01414 * #> --- #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #> #> Residual standard error: 7037 on 175 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared: 0.2605, Adjusted R-squared: 0.2394 #> F-statistic: 12.33 on 5 and 175 DF, p-value: 2.981e-10 ``` ::: ::: When compared to the reference level, the 'enginetypeohc' and 'enginetypeohcv' categories have statistically significant effects on the price. The other categories ('enginetypedohcv,' 'enginetypel,' and 'enginetypeohcf') do not have statistically significant effects based on the p-values.

enginetypeohc: The estimated decrease in price for cars with 'enginetypeohc' compared to the reference level is $7,025. The p-value (0.00112) is less than 0.05, so the effect is statistically significant at the 0.05 significance level.

enginetypeohcv: The estimated increase in price for cars with 'enginetypeohcv' compared to the reference level is $6,982. The p-value (0.01414) is less than 0.05, so the effect is statistically significant at the 0.05 significance level.

Changing the value of 'enginetype' involves comparing the effect of different engine types on the predicted price ::: {.cell hash='03_regression_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-6_86551703a299cae0dd3013b43b3ab87d'} ```{.r .cell-code} #5 library(dplyr) # Add a new variable 'seat_heating' with value TRUE for all observations new_df <- data %>% mutate(seat_heating = TRUE) # Run a regression with the new variable model_with_seat_heating <- lm(price ~ . + seat_heating, data = new_df) # Print the summary of the linear regression model summary(model_with_seat_heating) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> #> Call: #> lm(formula = price ~ . + seat_heating, data = new_df) #> #> Residuals: #> Min 1Q Median 3Q Max #> -5662 -1120 0 798 9040 #> #> Coefficients: (1 not defined because of singularities) #> Estimate Std. 167.148 0.926 0.355761 #> seat_heatingTRUE NA NA NA NA #> --- #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #> #> Residual standard error: 2189 on 143 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared: 0.9415, Adjusted R-squared: 0.9264 #> F-statistic: 62.21 on 37 and 143 DF, p-value: < 2.2e-16 ``` ::: ::: Perfect Collinearity: If the new variable has the same value for all observations (in this case, TRUE for all), it will lead to perfect collinearity. Perfect collinearity occurs when one variable can be exactly predicted from another variable or a combination of other variables in the model. In such cases, the regression model cannot estimate the coefficients separately, resulting in NA coefficients.

Perfect Prediction: If the new variable is perfectly predictive of the dependent variable, the regression model may not be able to estimate the coefficients due to perfect prediction. This can occur when there is no variability in the dependent variable within each level of the new variable.
